soc.client

Class ClientNetwork

  • java.lang.Object
    • soc.client.ClientNetwork

  • class ClientNetwork
extends java.lang.Object
    Helper object to encapsulate and deal with SOCPlayerClient's network connectivity.

    Local practice server (if any) is started in startPracticeGame(String, SOCGameOptionSet). Local tcp server (if any) is started in initLocalServer(int).
    Messages from server to client are received in either MemConnection.run() or NetConnection.run(), which call the client's MessageHandler.handle(SOCMessage, Connection).
    Messages from client to server are formed in GameMessageSender or other classes, which call back here to send to the server via Connection.send(SOCMessage).
    Network shutdown is disconnect() or dispose().

    Before v2.0.00, most of these fields and methods were part of the main SOCPlayerClient class.

    Since:
    3.0.00
    Author:
    Paul Bilnoski <paul@bilnoski.net>
    See Also:
    SOCPlayerClient.getNet()

    • Field Detail

      • SOC_PORT_DEFAULT

        public static final int SOC_PORT_DEFAULT
        Default tcp port number 8880 to listen, and to connect to remote server. Should match SOCServer.SOC_PORT_DEFAULT.

        8880 is the default SOCPlayerClient port since jsettlers 1.0.4, per cvs history.

        Since:
        1.1.00
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • CONNECT_TIMEOUT_MS

        public static int CONNECT_TIMEOUT_MS
        Timeout for initial connection to server; default is 6000 milliseconds.

      • serverConnectInfo

        protected ServerConnectInfo serverConnectInfo
        Server connection info. null until Connection.connect( boolean ) is called. Unlike connect params, localhost is not represented here as null: see ServerConnectInfo.hostname javadoc.

        Versions before 2.2.00 instead had host and port fields.

        Since:
        2.2.00

      • localServer

        SOCServer localServer
        Client-hosted server. It may be a TCP server (SOCServer.SOCServer(int,int,String,String) Started via SwingMainDisplay.startLocalTCPServer(int), or an intra-JVM server SOCServer.SOCServer(String) started via startPracticeServer(). Clients referencing field need not be aware of its underlying implementation.
        Since:
        1.1.00

      • isPracticeGame

        boolean isPracticeGame

      • ex

        java.lang.Exception ex
        Any network error (TCP communication) received while connecting or sending messages in netConnect(String, int), or null. If ex != null, putNet will refuse to send.

        The exception's toString() including its getMessage() may be displayed to the user by SOCPlayerClient.shutdownFromNetwork(); if throwing an error that the user should see, be sure to set the detail message.

        See Also:
        ex_P

      • ex_P

        java.lang.Exception ex_P
        Practice-server error (stringport pipes), or null.

        Before v2.0.00 this field was ex_L (Local server).

        Since:
        1.1.00
        See Also:
        ex

    • Constructor Detail

      • ClientNetwork

        public ClientNetwork(SOCPlayerClient playerClient)
        Create our client's ClientNetwork. Before using the ClientNetwork, caller client must construct their GUI and call setMainDisplay(MainDisplay). Then, call Connection.connect( boolean ).

        Parameters:
        practiceGameName - Game name
        gameOpts - Game options, or null
        Returns:

      • memConnect

        public void memConnect()
                throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
        Attempts to connect to a local server. See SOCPlayerClient.isConnected() for success or failure. Once connected, starts a client MessageHandler thread. The first message sent from client to server is our SOCVersion. Upon connection, if server is full, it sends a SOCRejectConnection message, otherwise it sends SOCVersion and current channels and games (SOCChannels, SOCGames).
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if already connected or otherwise unable to connect
        See Also:
        SOCServer.newConnection1(Connection)

      • netConnect

        public void netConnect(java.lang.String host,
                       int port)
                throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
        Attempts to connect to a TCP server. See SOCPlayerClient.isConnected() for success or failure. Once connected, starts a client MessageHandler thread. The first message sent from client to server is our SOCVersion. Upon connection, if server is full, it sends a SOCRejectConnection message, otherwise it sends SOCVersion and current channels and games (SOCChannels, SOCGames).

        Since user login and authentication don't occur until a game or channel join is requested, no username or password is needed here.

        Parameters:
        host - Server host to connect to, or null for localhost
        port - Server TCP port to connect to; the default server port is SOC_PORT_DEFAULT.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if already connected or if Version.versionNumber() returns 0 (packaging error)
        See Also:
        SOCServer.newConnection1(Connection)

      • disconnect

        protected void disconnect()
        Disconnect from the net (client of remote server). If a problem occurs, sets ex.
        See Also:
        dispose()

        public boolean isRunningLocalServer()

      • anyHostedActiveGames

        public boolean anyHostedActiveGames()

        Returns:

        Since:

        See Also:
